Senegal - Projet de Developpement Rural
            du Senegal Oriental

abstracts.cdata!:
This is the Project Completion Report
            (PCR) for the Eastern Senegal Rural Development Project in
            Senegal. The principal project objectives were: (a) to
            increase production of cotton, the main cash crop in the
            area, and cereals grown as rotation crops; (b) to organize
            farmer groups and help them assume more responsibility for
            primary marketing, application for credit and credit
            recovery, and investment decisions; (c) to promote the
            integration of crop and livestock activities, including
            consolidation of achievement under the then ongoing
            Livestock Project; (d) to develop essential rural
            infrastructure;  and (e) to improve the operational and
            financial efficiency of Cotton Development Agency. Cotton
            production fell substantially short of appraisal projections
            because farmers found groundnut cultivation more
            remunerative due to the relatively high groundnut producer
            prices set by the Government and the low return to labor on
            cotton. The problem worsened with the reduction of cotton
            input subsidies in 1986. As a result, cotton acreage
            declined and never reached pre-project levels during
            Implementation: total seed cotton production declined from
            46,900 t in 1984 to 29,300 t in 1990 before rebounding
            however to 44,900 t in 1991. Millet/sorghum production also
            fell short of expectations. Estimates had put the acreage
            under these two crops at 31,040 ha and per hectare yields at
            1,100 kg for the year 1989/90, but only 27,186 ha (88
            percent of estimated acreage) and 1,000kg/ha (91 percent of
            appraisal estimate) were accomplished.
